:+1: Please squash your commits

@himanshug any more comments?
@drcrallen why did this come up? It seems like the real problem is that something is keeping around indexes that it shouldn't be keeping around…

@gianm https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2149#discussion_r48765961

Mostly because it is easy to screw up keeping indexes around. I had a similar problem in the spark batch indexer because I was handling the reference to the incremental index in an inefficient manner. It is a very easy mistake to make, and this change is intended to minimize its impact. Though yes, you are correct, having the incremental index object itself garbage collected properly is the preferred route.

I like the move into an `optimize` method inside the filter.

@fjy I agree with your comments that having a separation of query -> plan -> rewrite -> plan -> execution totally makes sense.  However, I don't think it makes sense for the current query path.  I think that work should come as part of a new query path.  It shouldn't be too difficult to adjust the internals to enable us to have a different query path that operates on top of the same set of segments, once that's in place it should be possible to experiment with a new query path.

For now, I don't think that should block this PR.

I'm :+1:.
Well, I'm :+1: once tests pass anyway.

The way it was working was to drop the table then try to stop the future. This version stops the future first, and then deletes the table. That way the future won't be trying to do crazy stuff on a deleted table, and the drop table command isn't waiting to be interleaved between whatever the future is doing.

Thanks @KurtYoung for working on this, this will be a very nice improvement.
I have just a few asks that might make reviewing this PR easier:
- Do you mind updating the PR description to reflect the overall changes you propose, so we don't have to read through all the comments?
- Would it be possible to break out separate PRs for the pieces that are independent, such as the addition of new compressedvsize classes? That will make reviewing the code change much easier and also help get things merged faster.
  Thanks!
@gianm Addressed your PR comments, I'm leaving the commit unsquashed for now for easier reference

I also have test TmpFileIOPeon with different buffer size to improve index merger performance,  but i find with small data the performance can increase, but with big data the performance just the same and find the bottleneck is CPU.

hi, @xvrl , we can divide this PR into 3 main parts:
1. Changing of **ColumnPartSerde**'s interface. I had change ColumnPartSerde's interface to separate the Serializer and Deserializer. So we can have multiple serializers, one of it has the same behavior with old ones. And another one is the new streaming version. The Deserializer just do the same thing like old ones.
2. Added **IndexedIntsWriter** interface and some *Writers which are responsible for writing dimension ids. You can see the hierarchy that i divided the writers to 2 main sub abstract classes: SingleValueIndexedIntsWriter and MultiValueIndexedIntsWriter. 
   Here are the classed which are doing the real things:
   **VSizeIndexedIntsWriter** (single value, vsize encoded, not compressed)
   **CompressedIntsIndexedWriter** (single value, not vsize encoded, compressed)
   **CompressedVSizeIntsIndexedWriter** (single value, vsize encoded, compressed)
   **VSizeIndexedWriter** (multi value, both offset and values are vsized, not compressed)
   **CompressedVSizeIndexedV3Writer** (multi value, only values are vsized, compressed)
   More details can be found here: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/druid-development/0CxhljSGeeo
3.  **GenericColumnSerializer** and its sub-classes are for writing metrics. They are almost identical to MetricColumnSerializer you familiar with, except the GenericColumnSerializer can write to a Channel(which is allocated from smoosher when building). The sub-classes are:
   **LongColumnSerializer** (write long metrics)
   **FloatColumnSerializer** (write float metrics)
   **ComplexColumnSerializer** (writer complex metrics)

I found that ImmutableRoaringBitmap.flip() still has bug even with new version
and results in incorrect result of NotFilter.
(MutableRoaringBitmap and RoaringBitmap work fine)
So, I submitted PR to fix the bug to RoaringBitmap.

I think it needs following
- fix RoaringBitmap bug
- release new version of RoaringBitmap with no flip bug
- release new version of bytebuffer-collections that reflect the new version of RoaringBitmap
- update pom.xml of Druid

Then, I'll add unit test codes to test bitmap complement.

So I think it'd be good to have both versions available and default to the old one for a few releases.

I can only see the result order being part of cacheKey for only TimeSeriesQuery, 
I believe this needs to be added for all other queries as well since the descending flag is part of BaseQuery. Also we seem to be missing unit tests for caching of reverse queries.

Ideally there would be some general UT way of doing it, but for the purposes of this PR I think a mock of the CF API and calling push directly is sufficient.

One key problem with a general UT for pushing is that the pushers do not have a unified way of how push is handled. As such there would need to be a lot of plugability layers to make sure that all deep storage paradigms work. It is not immediately obvious such an approach would be better than just having each deep storage implementation handle its own Push unit test.

There is a mention about intervals in the document about timeseries queries.(http://druid.io/docs/latest/querying/timeseriesquery.html)
`Time buckets that lie completely outside the data interval are not zero-filled.`

The time buckets in a query result is not continuous when data is not available between disjoint segments. This is because the resulting time buckets are produced based on existing data intervals, not query itself. Inside a single segment level, zero filling would work well.
In my opinion, this might confuse some people because they expect the time buckets is continuous and based on the given query interval no matter how data is stored.
Does it need to be fixed in the way the returned time buckets are based on query interval?
